lcn.p: Easy it is to have compassion for one who has never done wrong in your eyes. Slightly harder it is to for compassion for one who has crossed you in one way or another. Hardest of all is to have compassion for one whom you believe has done something heinous - even more one who has done countless heinous things.

Nonetheless, we must strive in our Jedi discipline to do all of that - for the darkness that possessed the greatest villains of history lusts to possess us as well -- and it will succeed in doing so if our compassion is reserved for those who do right in our eyes.

This, of course, does not mean that we must condone acts of evil. We must still take any appropriate action against everything from extreme evil to minor mischief. This merely means that we must take this action from a place of compassion.
But surely we must avoid judging bad actions to be good, or even benign, just because doing so would make it easier to be compassionate toward the one who committed such actions.

For this reason, we must train ourselves so that we no longer see a condemnation of someone's actions, even the resolve to make an appropriate response to those actions as being in any way incompatible with being compassionate toward that same someone.
